EXIT   X

TERRORIST  FINANCING

Page

Table of Contents

Stolen car parts

 

In November 2005 and March 2006, thirteen men were arrested and charged with terrorism offences in relation to being members of a local terrorist organisation led by Mr Benbrika.

 

As part of these arrests three of the thirteen men, Joud Raad, Ahmed Raad and Ezzit Raad, were convicted of attempting to make funds available to a terrorist organisation.

 

The court found that the three intended to provide these funds to the terrorist organisation through the sale of stolen car parts.

 

Both Joud and Ahmed Raad were sentenced to five years imprisonment. Ezzit Raad was sentenced to four years imprisonment.

 

Terrorists obtain money from a number of sources. For example:

 

Click on the terms below to see more details

There is evidence that other countries have been involved in supporting terrorists, either by assisting in the planning of attacks or by providing resources, safe harbours and other support to terrorist networks.

Terrorists may operate legitimate businesses, generating profit to finance their activities. Or they may receive donations from other legitimate businesses.

Money is made available from other individuals, including other terrorists or sympathisers, as well as organisations such as charities and religious organisations.

Money is laundered and then made available to terrorist organisations. This is particularly relevant to drug trafficking.

Stolen car parts
